body:
Thanks for opening this issue, @caprone!

1. `Environment` actually doesn't have a default value for `root_results_path`. I mention that in the documentation, but I realize that's a bit confusing since it is a keyword argument. The part of the documentation that might address your problem is **"If [`root_results_path` is] None or invalid, results will not be stored"**. 
So it sounds like your problem is that nothing is being saved because no `root_results_path` has been provided. Again, I realize now that this might be confusing, but do you think it would help to make `root_results_path` a required argument? Originally, I made it an optional kwarg for those that really didn't want to save the files.

2. Yes, that's a problem that I'm looking into solutions for. Currently, it attempts to maximize whatever metric its given (even if its a loss), which is, of course, a problem. I don't know of any way to automate this, so I imagine I'll add an additional kwarg to `Environment`, in which you can specify whether the metric should be maximized or minimized. Do you think that would take care of the problem for you?

Thanks again for your questions!

Great, I’m glad that’s cleared up and the documentation makes sense.

I see. Are you running the exact, unmodified, most recent `example/functionality_example` script? I just tried running it again, and everything went smoothly, so can you tell me a bit about your environment? OS? Python version? XGBoost version? HyperparameterHunter version? 

Thanks for your feedback, I’ll get to work on that unless you’ve got an idea and would like to submit a pull request?

Currently, the way to look at the varying hyperparameters and recorded scores for a set of experiments using the same algorithm involves reading the “GlobalLeaderboard.csv” to find the experiment ids you’re interested in, then opening the .json description files created for those experiments, in which you can find all hyperparameter and testing condition information. I hope to add algorithm-specific leaderboard files that will show hyperparameter values right on the leaderboard, but I haven’t gotten around to it yet.

Edit: It just occurred to me, that a workaround for your last question might be to start up an optimizer with very broad search boundaries, so as to pickup all the experiments you want to look at. Then, as it reads in the similar experiments, it displays a table of their scores and hyperparameters, which could be exactly what you're looking for. At least until other leaderboard files can be built. Again, if you have any ideas for these I would welcome and very much appreciate any PRs! Thanks again for opening this issue!
a ok, perfect, I think it is a good solution

Great! Since the primary issue here now seems to be the need to tell the optimizer to minimize/maximize depending on the primary metric used, I'll close this issue as this is also mentioned in #34. If you disagree, please let me know, and we can reopen this! Thanks a lot for voicing your support for that feature!

issue.title: hyperparameter space issue

repository.name: hyperparameter_hunter
repository.description: Easy hyperparameter optimization and automatic result saving across machine learning algorithms and libraries

issue.body:
HI
ther's a problem when You try to rerun the optimizer with 'exactly' the same
 hyperparameters's range of values;

for example, if I declare: 
'max_depth'=Integer(2, 15) 
and any other Real hyperpar., for ex.:
 'min_split_loss'=(...)
 the  hyper_space_size will be: np.inf;

then it make sense to rerun optimizer  also with high interations(in the same space);
but if I try to do that, the following Uncaught exception occur:

"Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:/MachinLrn/Esperiments_Prjct/scripts/one.py", line 135, in <module>
    execute()
  File "D:/MachinLrn/Esperiments_Prjct/scripts/one.py", line 109, in execute
    optimizer.go()  # Now, we go
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization.py", line 87, in go
    super().go()
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization_core.py", line 340, in go
    self._optimization_loop()
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization_core.py", line 364, in _optimization_loop
    if len(self.similar_experiments) + len(self.tested_keys) >= self.search_space_size:
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization_core.py", line 802, in search_space_size
    self._search_space_size = len(self.hyperparameter_space)
TypeError: 'float' object cannot be interpreted as an integer

then if I change the max_depth range , like (2, 14) and rerun optimizer, all works well, again...

issue.title: `tell` optimizer positive/negative utility values depending on `target_metric`

repository.name: hyperparameter_hunter
repository.description: Easy hyperparameter optimization and automatic result saving across machine learning algorithms and libraries

issue.body:
- Update the following methods of `optimization_core.InformedOptimizationProtocol`:
  - `_execute_experiment`
  - `_find_similar_experiments`
- The two aforementioned methods are the two locations at which `optimization_core.InformedOptimizationProtocol.optimizer` is "`tell`-ed" the utility value of a set of hyperparameters
- Currently, a negative utility value is provided to `optimizer`, which will cause problems if `target_metric` should be minimized
  - This is the case when `target_metric` is some loss measure
- Need to add a means of specifying that positive utility values should be used, instead of negative, or of detecting that `target_metric` measures loss

body: @caprone, I posted a temporary workaround for using loss/error metrics [here](https://github.com/HunterMcGushion/hyperparameter_hunter/issues/34#issuecomment-434506619) that may help you until the real fix is made
